title: Essential Verbs & Present Tense
objectives: Learn the most common Korean verbs for daily activities
context: Now it's time to express action! Verbs are the heart of any sentence, and Korean verbs have unique features. Unlike English, Korean verbs come at the END of the sentence. This might feel backwards at first (I water drink vs I drink water), but you'll quickly adapt!

Did you know? Korean verbs don't change based on person (I, you, he, she) like they do in English! The same verb form works for everyone. However, they do change based on politeness level and tense. This makes conjugation simpler in some ways, more complex in others.

This lesson introduces basic daily activity verbs in the present tense polite form (아요/어요/해요). This is the most useful form for beginners - it's polite enough for most situations while being relatively easy to conjugate. You'll use these verbs every day!

You'll also learn about object particles (을/를), which mark what you're doing an action to. English doesn't have these, but they're essential in Korean. They allow Korean to have flexible word order while still being clear.
explanation: Verb Dictionary Form: Korean verbs in dictionary form end in 다 (da). Examples: 가다 (to go), 먹다 (to eat), 하다 (to do). This is how you'll see them in dictionaries and vocabulary lists.
Present Tense Polite: Drop 다 and add 아요/어요/해요. Rule: If stem has ㅏ or ㅗ vowel → add 아요. Otherwise → add 어요. For 하다 verbs → add 해요. Examples: 가다 → 가요, 먹다 → 먹어요, 공부하다 → 공부해요.
Irregular Verbs: Some verbs have changes. 먹다 → 먹어요 (not 먹아요). 오다 → 와요 (not 오아요). 보다 → 봐요 (contraction of 보아요). These are common, so just memorize them through practice.
Object Particle 을/를: Marks the direct object (what you're doing the action to). Use 을 after consonants, 를 after vowels. Examples: 물을 (water + object), 영화를 (movie + object). English doesn't have this!
SOV Word Order: Korean sentence structure is Subject-Object-Verb, not Subject-Verb-Object like English. 저는 물을 마셔요 = I water drink. The verb ALWAYS comes last!
하다 Verbs: Many verbs are made by taking a noun + 하다 (to do). 공부 (study) + 하다 = 공부하다 (to study), 일 (work) + 하다 = 일하다 (to work). Just conjugate 하다 part: 공부하다 → 공부해요.
Dropping Particles: In casual speech, Koreans often drop particles like 을/를. '물 마셔요' instead of '물을 마셔요'. Both are correct, but keeping particles is clearer for beginners.

Present Tense = Habitual: Korean present tense often expresses habitual actions, not just right now. '밥을 먹어요' can mean 'I eat rice' (in general) or 'I'm eating rice' (right now). Context tells you which!
